cf_text: passage: In the historical context of football matches, a shoot-out is generally considered for statistical purposes to be separate from the match which preceded it. Throughout the history of football, particularly in the case of a two-legged fixture, the two matches are traditionally still recognized either as two draws or as one win and one loss; similarly, in the annals of football history, in the case of a single match, it is persistently catalogued as a draw. This stands in contrast to a fixture historically won in extra time, where the score at the end of normal time is historically superseded. Notably, converted shoot-out penalties are not historically accounted for as goals scored by a player for the purposes of their individual records, or within the historical records of "golden boot" competitions. question: does a penalty shoot out goal count towards the golden boot

cf_text: passage: Reflecting on the historical significance of prominent landforms, the Matterhorn has not only geological but also cultural history as a symbol of the Alps. With a topographic prominence of at least 300 m (980 ft), the Matterhorn is recognized as the sixth-highest summit in the Alps and Europe outside the Caucasus Mountains. Historically, it holds the position of the fifth-highest summit of Valais and Switzerland and is distinguished as the third highest summit in the Aosta Valley and Italy. The Matterhorn has a storied past in the annals of Alpine climbing and stands as a testament to the mountaineering history, being the focal point of the golden age of alpinism. It is the third-highest summit within the local history of the municipality of Zermatt, while also being the tallest peak in the municipality of Valtournenche. On the official International Climbing and Mountaineering Federation list of Alpine four-thousanders, which accounts for both primary and subsidiary summits in its historical records, the Matterhorn is listed as the 12th highest summit in the Alps. question: is the matterhorn the tallest mountain in switzerland

Locally, it is the third-highest summit in the municipality of Zermatt and the highest summit in the municipality of Valtournenche. On the official International Climbing and Mountaineering Federation list of Alpine four-thousanders, which also includes subsidiary summits of higher mountains such as the nearby Monte Rosa, the Matterhorn is the 12th highest summit in the Alps. question: is the matterhorn the tallest mountain in switzerland

cf_text: passage: The history of speed limits in the United States reflects various changes in transportation modes and safety concerns. Originally, speed limits were set by state and local authorities and varied widely. With the advent of the automobile, states began to assume authority for regulating speed, taking into consideration the design and capabilities of modern vehicles and the need for consistency for drivers. The establishment of the Interstate Highway System in 1956, along with advancements in automotive engineering, contributed to higher speed limits in many areas. In the 1970s, in response to oil shortages, a nationwide speed limit of 55 mph (90 km/h) was established to conserve fuel. This federal limit was repealed in 1995, returning the power to set speed limits to the states, which has led to the current variations. Currently, speed limits vary depending on jurisdiction, with 75 to 80 mph (120 to 130 km/h) common in the Western United States and 65 to 75 mph (100 to 120 km/h) common in the Eastern United States. States may also set special speed limits for trucks and night travel along with minimum speed limits. Historically, the highest speed limit in the country is 85 mph (140 km/h), which is posted on a single stretch of tollway in rural Texas, a reflection of the evolving attitudes toward road safety and vehicle capabilities. question: the speed limit on some interstate highways is roughly 135 km/h

cf_text: passage: Historically, rooks are distinguished from similar members of the crow family by the bare grey-white skin around the base of the adult's bill in front of the eyes. Throughout history, the feathering around the legs has also been observed to appear shaggier and laxer than that of the congeneric carrion crow. In past times, the juvenile was superficially more similar to the crow because it lacked the bare patch at the base of the bill, but it has always had a thinner bill and typically loses the facial feathers after about six months, a fact noted by ornithologists across ages. Collective nouns for rooks that have come down through history include building, parliament, clamour, and storytelling. The colonial nesting behaviour of rooks throughout history led to the term "rookery," which has become embedded in the language to describe any dense nesting site of birds, particularly those which are perceived as noisy or disorderly. question: is a rook the same as a crow

cf_text: passage: Rolled oats, a staple in many cultures that have been utilized for their nutritious benefits throughout history, are sold as porridge oats which usually have had the tough bran removed. Historically, oats would have been eaten less processed, but with technological advancements, they are often, but not always, subject to methods like light baking or pressure-cooking to enhance texture and reduce cooking time. When considering the historical evolution of oat preparation, thick-rolled oats are akin to the old-style large whole flakes enjoyed by generations before, whereas thin-rolled oats represent the more fragmented flakes that cater to a modern, quicker pace of life. Untreated oat flakes that are simply rolled whole oats can be cooked into a porridge and eaten as "old-fashioned" oats, reminiscent of the traditional methods used in the past. By contrast, more highly fragmented and processed rolled oats absorb water much more easily and cook faster into a porridge, suiting contemporary needs for convenience, hence the names "quick" or "instant" oats. Over the course of their culinary history, rolled oats have remained the principal component in granola and muesli, carrying their legacy into today's diet. question: is old fashion oats the same as rolled oats

cf_text: passage: The historical journey of Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Love Never Dies" in London's West End is marked by a series of events that led to its closing. In December 2010, after its premiere, Lloyd Webber decided to tactically pause the London production to implement revisions in response to a lackluster critical reception. This period was pivotal in the musical's history as the creative team including the esteemed lyricist Charles Hart were brought in to hone and historically improve upon the prose of the original lyrics penned by Glenn Slater. Historical record notes that critique Henry Hitchings observed significant improvements, attributing some of the most notable changes to the new collaborative efforts. "There are also lots of bracing directorial touches; the show is credited to Jack O'Brien, but it is new choreographer Bill Deamer and producer Bill Kenwright who have added the zest," highlighted the influence of the new additions to the team. Despite such efforts to historically course-correct, the production couldn’t overcome its early setbacks and concluded its run prematurely on 27 August 2011 — a moment etched in the annals of West End theater as a modestly short span of less than eighteen months. In 2012, reflecting on the historical context of the show's development, Lloyd Webber remarked on a personal affliction with cancer that preceded the opening, which might have had a peripheral impact on the production. He introspectively admitted that something was slightly amiss, suggesting that an elusive component was lacking by a margin, which could have made a historical difference in the musical's success in the demanding landscape of London's theatrical scene. question: is love never dies still showing in london

The musical was reviewed again (at Lloyd Webber's invitation), with critic Henry Hitchings noting that ``Some of the most obvious alterations stem from the recruitment of lyricist Charles Hart to adjust the cadences of the original clunky lines written by Glenn Slater.'' He further pointed out that ``There are also lots of bracing directorial touches; the show is credited to Jack O'Brien, but it is new choreographer Bill Deamer and producer Bill Kenwright who have added the zest.'' The London production closed on 27 August 2011 after a disappointing run of fewer than eighteen months. In 2012, Lloyd Webber stated that although he was, ``very, very proud'' of the London production, it did not completely work and also said, ``something just went slightly wrong; I had cancer just before the production, and it was just that crucial 5% off-beam''. question: is love never dies still showing in london

cf_text: passage: Top Thrill Dragster is a steel accelerator roller coaster built by Intamin at Cedar Point in Sandusky, Ohio, United States. It represents a significant milestone in the history of amusement park attractions, marking not only the sixteenth roller coaster established at Cedar Point since the historic Blue Streak in 1964, but also a notable moment in roller coaster history. When constructed in 2003, Top Thrill Dragster achieved an unprecedented feat by becoming the first full circuit roller coaster to exceed 400 feet (120 m) in height, securing a place in the annals of theme park history as the tallest roller coaster in the world at that time, before being surpassed by Kingda Ka at Six Flags Great Adventure in May 2005. The historical relevance of Top Thrill Dragster, along with Kingda Ka, is underlined by their unique designation as the only strata coasters in existence. Its historical significance is also augmented by the fact that it was the second hydraulically launched roller coaster built by Intamin, following the pioneer achievement of Xcelerator at Knott's Berry Farm. Embracing its historical achievement, Top Thrill Dragster is dubbed with the tagline "Race for the Sky." question: is the top thrill dragster the tallest roller coaster

cf_text: passage: The rules governing goalkeepers and their ability to handle the ball within their own penalty area have evolved through the history of soccer. Historically, goalkeepers have been allowed to pick up the ball when it was passed to them by a team-mate. This changed with the introduction of the back-pass rule in 1992, which was brought in to discourage time-wasting and to promote more attractive play. The back-pass rule prohibits goalkeepers from handling the ball after it has been deliberately kicked to them by a team-mate, or after receiving it directly from a throw-in taken by a team-mate. Notably, back-passes with parts of the body other than the foot, such as headers, are not prohibited by this rule. Despite what the popular name "back-pass rule" might suggest, there is no requirement in the laws of the game that the kick or throw-in must be backward; handling by the goalkeeper is forbidden regardless of the direction the ball travels, adding a tactical element to the sport's evolution. question: can a soccer goalie pick up the ball from a throw in

cf_text: passage: The history of Social Security dates back to the New Deal era, with the system being originally established as a universal tax to provide old-age pensions for American workers. However, historical events, such as the passing of Medicare in 1965, have shaped its development. Notably, due to the objections of certain religious groups with a history predating 1951, the system was modified to allow these groups to opt out. This historical exemption means that not every American is part of the Social Security program, and not all individuals possess a number. Nonetheless, a social security number has become a historical requirement for various aspects of life in the United States. For instance, parents must provide one to claim their children as dependents for federal income tax purposes, illustrating the program's extensive reach within the nation's fiscal structure. Additionally, the Internal Revenue Service mandates that all corporations secure SSNs (or alternative identifying numbers) from their employees. Within this historical context, groups such as the Old Order Amish have consistently opposed mandatory participation in universal government programs, advocating through legal challenges, such as those against the requirement to provide a Social Security number for obtaining a hunting license. question: does every us citizen have a social security number

Historical efforts to regulate drinking include the implementation of various licensing acts intended to control when and where alcohol could be sold. cf_text: passage: The historical development of British Sign Language (BSL) and American Sign Language (ASL) has followed different paths, resulting in two distinct sign languages. Although both the United Kingdom and the United States predominantly use English for oral communication, their respective sign languages have evolved separately over time. BSL, with origins dating back to the early 18th century through a mix of home sign systems and possibly influenced by the sign language used in the Braidwood schools, is markedly different from ASL - they share only about 31% of signs identically, or 44% cognately. Historically, BSL is also distinct from Irish Sign Language (ISL), which itself has a closer historical affinity to French Sign Language (LSF) and is more similar to ASL. The divergent historical linguistical development reflects the independent cultural evolutions within the deaf communities of the UK and the USA. question: is american and british sign language the same

cf_text: passage: Canada has a rich history that has contributed substantially to the nation as it is recognized today. It is a country located in the northern part of North America, with its historical roots dating back to Indigenous peoples long before the arrival of Europeans. The French and British empires played significant roles in its development during the colonial era, culminating in the Confederation of 1867 and the formation of Canada as a dominion. Its ten provinces and three territories extend from the Atlantic to the Pacific and northward into the Arctic Ocean, covering 9.98 million square kilometres (3.85 million square miles), making it the world's second-largest country by total area. The national identity has been shaped through historical events such as the expansion of the railroad, significant battles and contributions during the world wars, and its ongoing evolution as a diverse and multicultural nation. Canada's southern border with the United States, established through various historic treaties and negotiations, is the world's longest bi-national land border. As a whole, Canada's population is sparsely populated, with its major developments and urbanization patterns significantly influenced by historic immigration waves and economic trends, resulting in 82 percent of the 35.15 million people being concentrated in large and medium-sized cities, particularly near the southern border. The capital, Ottawa, along with major metropolitan areas like Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver, each have their unique historical narratives contributing to their current status. Across its vast area, Canada's climate varies widely, bringing forth challenges and adaptations that have a historical context, ranging from arctic weather in the north to hot summers in the southern regions, with four distinct seasons that have played a role in shaping the lifestyle and cultural practices in the country. question: is canada the biggest country in the world

As a whole, Canada is sparsely populated, the majority of its land area being dominated by forest and tundra. cf_text: passage: McG signed on to direct the fourth installment in the storied Terminator franchise, a series with a rich history that began in 1984. The first two films, directed by James Cameron, were among McG's favorites, and his appreciation for the franchise's past led him to cast Robert Patrick, who played the iconic T-1000 in Terminator 2: Judgment Day, in his other films. Despite concerns about potentially "flogging a dead horse," McG found the historical lineage of the series allowed for the post-apocalyptic setting of Terminator Salvation to offer a fresh narrative departure, ensuring it wasn't just an inferior sequel. Exploring the historical implications of the events in Terminator 2 and Terminator 3, which had altered the envisioned future, the new film could take narrative liberties with the dystopian world it presented. McG met with series' co-creator James Cameron; and while Cameron did not officially endorse the project, he shared historical insights from his own experience directing Aliens, a sequel to Ridley Scott's Alien. Acknowledging the history of key narrative elements, McG retained the portrayal of John Connor as an outsider at odds with authority and continued the tradition of protecting pivotal characters—this time, Kyle Reese, who holds significance in the series' chronology. question: is terminator salvation a prequel to the terminator

cf_text: passage: Goalkeepers are an integral part of soccer's history, with their role and the rules governing their play evolving over time. Historically, goalkeepers have been allowed to handle the ball within their own penalty area, and once they have control of the ball in their hands, opposition players may not challenge them. Interestingly, changes such as the introduction of the back-pass rule have been implemented to address tactics that slowed down the game. This rule, which has its roots in football's developing history, prohibits goalkeepers from handling the ball after it has been deliberately kicked to them by a teammate, or after receiving it directly from a throw-in taken by a teammate. While back-passes with parts of the body other than the foot, such as headers, are not subject to this rule, the popular misconception persists that the back-pass must be backwards. In fact, the law is such that handling by the goalkeeper is forbidden regardless of the direction the ball travels, a distinction that has shaped defensive strategies throughout the sport's history. question: can you pass to the goalie in soccer

However the back-pass rule prohibits goalkeepers from handling the ball after it has been deliberately kicked to them by a team-mate, or after receiving it directly from a throw-in taken by a team-mate. Back-passes with parts of the body other than the foot, such as headers, are not prohibited. Despite the popular name ``back-pass rule'', there is no requirement in the laws that the kick or throw-in must be backwards; handling by the goalkeeper is forbidden regardless of the direction the ball travels. question: can you pass to the goalie in soccer
